10. We look forward to seeing you in the field this Saturday. I thank your attention.Prof. Mahmood YakubuINEC Chairman
9. I urge you all to keep to the rules, listen to the presentation to be made shortly and ask questions where you require further clarification.

8. Do not interfere with the process or show partisanship. In addition, international observers must be guided by the fact that the election is conducted by the Federal Republic of Nigeria whose sovereignty must be respected.

7. Today‚Äôs briefing for observers is in keeping with international good practice. I wish to remind observers that there is a code of conduct for election observation. You are by definition observers.

6. The Commission accredited 33 international organisations deploying 2,113 observers. In all, 229 groups are deploying 146,913 observers for the #NigeriaDecides2023. This is the largest deployment of domestic and international observers in the history of elections in Nigeria.

5. The implication is that all accredited observers are guests of INEC. For the #NigeriaDecides2023 beginning this weekend with the Presidential & Nat. Assembly elections, INEC has accredited 196 national or domestic groups that are collectively deploying 144,800 observers.

4. The progressive improvement in our electoral democracy since 1999 draws in part from the reports of observers and the study tours. That is why over the years, the Commission has sent open or specific invitations to national and international observers.
3. The reports and recommendations of observers and the knowledge from the study tours help electoral commissions to progressively improve processes.

2. As a consequence, observers submit reports to electoral commissions highlighting strengths and weaknesses of processes. Arising from study tours, election managers also learn from other jurisdictions.

1. I welcome you all to this briefing for accredited election observers. In line with global good practice, electoral commissions in most jurisdictions invite national & international organisations to deploy observers or organise study tours for election managers during elections

39. Once again, I welcome you to this meeting. Thank you and God bless.Prof. Mahmood YakubuINEC Chairman

38. I also call on the security, intelligence and law enforcement agencies to arrest, investigate and prosecute anyone involved in violent conduct, including incendiary statements capable of inciting a breach of the peace.
37. Let me once again appeal to Chairman and leaders of political parties to continue to call your candidates and supporters to order.

36. Turning to the ongoing  electioneering campaigns, the Commission is concerned about violent attacks on supporters of political parties across the board, resulting in the loss of life in some cases.
35. Only Identification tags issued by the Commission will be recognised on election day and violators are liable to arrest and prosecution for impersonation.
34.  A situation where two or more agents claim to represent a political party, resulting in commotion at polling units or collation centres, is unacceptable.

33. I urge the Chairmen and leaders of political parties to ensure that only agents accredited by the Commission and wearing the correct identification tags appear at polling units and collation centres during elections.

32. The Commission is finalising the issuance of 1,642,386 identification tags for the Polling and Collation Agents nominated by the 18 political parties made up of 1,574,301 Polling Agents and 68,085 Collation Agents.
31. As you are already aware, we have less than two weeks to the 2023 General Election.

30. Voters can locate and confirm their polling units before election day by sending a regular text or WhatsApp message to a dedicated telephone number. Details of the simple procedure will be uploaded to our social media platforms shortly.

29. We have also compiled the register of such voters and our State offices will give it wide publicity, especially for those who may not have provided their telephone numbers during voter registration or those whose numbers may have changed.
28. In addition, all voters who have been assigned to new polling units will receive text messages from the Commission indicating their polling units.
27. This should not happen on election day. Consequently, the Commission is advising voters to confirm the locations of their polling units through a dedicated portal on our website.

26. From the feedback we received from our officials and accredited observers following the recent nationwide mock accreditation using the BVAS, it is clear that some voters could not easily identify their polling units.
25. Closely related to the distribution of voters is the identification of polling units.
24. Accordingly, the soft copy of the list has been uploaded to our website and social media platforms for public information and guidance.
23. Hard copies of the list are included in your folders for this meeting. Above all, Nigerians deserve the right to know the locations of these polling units.
22  With this development, the number of polling units where elections will hold nationwide on 25th February 2023 and 11th March 2023 is now 176,606.

21. In our avowed commitment to transparency, the Commission is making available to Nigerians a comprehensive list of these polling units by name, code number and their locations by State, Local Government and Registration Area.

20. No new registrants chose the polling units and no voters indicated interest to transfer to them during the last Continuous Voter Registration (CVR), mainly for security reasons. This means that no elections will hold in these polling units.

9. However, there are 240 polling units without registered voters spread across 28 States and the Federal Capital Territory (FCT). They range from one polling unit to 12 polling units in each State and the FCT, except Taraba & Imo States with 34 and 38 polling units respectively.

8. This requires the redistribution of voters to new polling units in proximate locations. Where they are separated by distance, this must be done after consultation with the voters. This has been done by our State offices nationwide.
7. At previous meetings, we also briefed you on our efforts to redistribute voters to the polling units in order to avoid the congestion that made voting cumbersome in many of them nationwide.
6. Consequently, the number of polling units increased from 119,973 to the current figure of 176,846.

5. Let me therefore start with the issue of polling units. You may recall that in 2021, with your support and that of other critical stakeholders, the Commission successfully expanded voter access to polling units 25 years after the last delimitation exercise in 1996.

4. We have consistently assured the leaders of political parties that the Commission will regularly consult you with a view to bringing you up to date on the preparations for the forthcoming elections.
3. We thank you for your presence and wish to assure you that meeting will not be long so that you can resume your campaigns and other activities towards the 2023 General Election.

2. I warmly welcome you all to this meeting. We appreciate that you are in the middle of your electioneering campaigns nationwide and yet found time to attend this meeting in spite of the short notice.

29. Some may include and not limited to the following: ‚úì The crave for sensational headlines‚úì The spectre of fake news‚úì The problem of planted stories ‚úì The breaking news syndrome‚úì Sources not willing to be named‚úì Information leakage from within
28. The Challenges: As Heads of Departments and Public Affairs Officers, you will face challenges. The challenges may come in different forms especially as election is by the corners.

27. ‚úì Basic knowledge of the constitutive legal instruments for the conduct of elections‚úì Understand the processes & procedures of the Commission‚úì Good understanding of the environment & the delimitation details of the state (Number of registration areas, polling units)

26. At the individual level, I have identified a few issues and challenges that must be on board as we approach the election.‚úì Personal Appearance ‚úì Composure and Comportment‚úì Personal Integrity ‚úì Good reading habit and documentation.

25. To perform effectively and optimally, there are irreducible minimums that must be met and must be present. Some of them have to do with the individual and others are related to the work of the Commission.
24. Heads of Departments and Public Affairs Officers interface between the Commission and the critical stakeholders at the State and Local Governments Levels.
23. Security is being beefed up in the State and Local Government Offices of the Commission and all the materials required for the election will be in place at least a week to the election.
22. All the sensitive and non sensitive materials required for the conduct of the 2023 General Election are being moved to location.

21. The Commission needs and will hire at least 100,000 buses and 4,000 boats for the election and the drivers and workers to be engaged must also subscribe to the Oath of Neutrality that will be administered by the Commission.

20. The Commission is engaging all institutions and critical national institutions supervising critical national assets. The Commission has revised and signed MOU with the National Union of Road Transport Workers and the Marine Workers Union of Nigeria.
19. All these categories of staff are undergoing training and the training of others will commence in a few days.

18. For the 2023 General Election, the Commission will recruit 707, 384 Presiding Officers & Assistant Presiding Officers, about 17, 685 Supervisory Presiding Officers, 9,620 Collation/Returning Officer, as well as 530,538 PU Security Officials, making a total of 1,265,227.

17. The Commission will also upload Polling Unit level results (Form EC8A) and the accreditation data to the INEC Result Viewing Portal. This is also a mandatory provision of section 50, 60 and 64 of the Electoral Act 2022.
16. The use of the BVAS for voter verification and authentication is a mandatory provision of section 47(2) of the Electoral Act and every registered voter must undergo the process of accreditation.
15. The Chairman of the Commission who supervised the entire process expressed satisfaction with the optimal performance of the BVAS in all the States of the Federation.

14. This took place on the 4th of February 2023 in all the 36 States of the Federation and the Federal Capital Territory, Abuja. Specifically, it took place in 218 Local Government Areas and 436 Polling Units.
13. Following improvements made to the hardware and software components of the BVAS, the Commission approved and carried out Mock Accreditation and Polling Unit Result Upload nationwide.

12. The Commission will also deploy redundancies to the 8,809 Registration Areas and the 774 LGAs of Nigeria. The Commission has tested the full complement of the BVAS that will be used for the election and they are presently being configured in readiness for the election.
11. The 2023 General Election will be technology driven. To this end, the Commission will deploy the Bimodal Voter Accreditation System (BVAS) to the 176,846 Polling Units across the Federation.
10. They will also elect 28 Governors and 993 members of the State Assembly. 93,469,008 registered voters are expected to participate in the #NigeriaDecides2023 election.

9. On the 25th of February and 11th of March 2023, Nigeria will elect a President for the Federal Republic of Nigeria. They will election 109 members of the Senate and 360 members of the House of Representatives.
8. The election will take place in the 176, 846 Polling Units of the Commission and the first level of collation will take place in the 8,809 Registration Areas (Electoral Wards).

7. The State of Preparations: The Commission will conduct National Elections (Presidential and National Assembly) on the 25th day of February 2023 and two weeks later on the 11th of March 2023, it will conduct State Elections (Governorship and State Assembly Elections).
6. Your role therefore is important in getting Nigerians to understand our policies, programs and procedures during the #NigeriaDecides2023 Election and thereafter.

5. Being Heads of Departments & Public Affairs Officers, it is your responsibility to advice the REC6s, and Electoral Officers on the best way to communicate the policies of the Commission, its technological innovations and issues in the conduct of elections.

4. It is also important against the backdrop of the coming into force of a new electoral legal framework for the conduct of elections and the Commission‚Äôs commitment to infuse technology in the electoral process.

18. I wish to appreciate the Directors of the Commission here present and thank the Director (Training) and her team for the arrangements put in place to organise this workshop.I hereby wish everyone a fruitful and successful workshop.Thank you.

17. I must also thank the Chair Board of Electoral Institute (BEI), Professor Abdullahi Abdu Zuru and other members of the Board for providing the visionary leadership necessary to propel the Institute to take giant strides to achieve its core mandate.
16. I also thank the Chairman of the Commission, Professor Mahmood Yakubu and all Members of the Commission for approving this workshop.

15. Let me at this juncture, thank our development partners @IFESNigeria for funding the review workshops and final production of the Handbook for Election Security Personnel as well as the Facilitators Guide.

14. As was earlier mentioned, we must get it right here, Otherwise, all other efforts will be futile, and counter productive. The 2023 General Election must be an improvement on the 2019 elections, a task that demands our collective and concerted efforts.

13. We are already working behind schedule, hence the need to hit the ground running.I once again wish to use this opportunity to enjoin all participants here present to ensure that we meet the objectives of this workshop.

12. Some of our headquarters core and certified trainers have also been invited to participate in the workshop. This will provide them with necessary know-how for supervision during the step-down training and to fill the gaps, in states where there may be need for such.

11. Therefore, enjoin participants to take up this challenge, to ensure that ultimately, security personnel deployed for the 2023 General Election in their respective states are well prepared through training for their responsibilities.

10. This 2-Days workshop will provide you the opportunity to sharpen your skills to effectively coordinate, manage and cascade Elections Security Personnel (ESP) Training in order to bring out the best and enhance high-level spirit of professionalism for optimal performance.
9. May I reiterate also that STOS have a huge responsibility ahead, but with this comes the opportunity to prove their worth.
8. Participants usually comprise high-ranking and middle-cadre security personnel, hence the need for facilitators to be on top of their game with regards to content and delivery.
7. However, while the Nigeria Police Force remains the coordinating body of ICCES members, other Security Agencies have representation at all levels of the training.

6. ...even beyond the 2023 General Election would be secured by well-trained security personnel, whose conduct would be professional in line with standard operational guidelines as stated in the ICCES Framework, It would also be in line with democratic norms.

5. These efforts are geared towards ensuring best practices such that at the conclusion of the cascade training which commences today at the National level to the States and Zonal level, it would leave no one in doubt that the Electoral environment leading up to and...
4. It is worthy of note that all Electoral Training Resources which include Security Training Manual and Handbook have not only been revised, but a Facilitators Guide has also been developed.

3. This workshop is important, because as a departure from previous tradition, we have a hybrid of participants made up of Security Agents and State Training Officers (STOS) from the 36 States and FCT who are to coordinate Electoral Security training in their respective states.

2. It is my pleasure to welcome you all to this timely and all-important workshop.Closely following the Readiness Assessment Workshop & in line with the Commission's approved Training Plan, the Electoral Security Personnel Training Workshop is today being kick-started by a ToT.

11. Finally, on behalf of IFES, we look forward to a productive dialogue session and wish you all a fruitful deliberation.Thank you!Obaje UkehDeputy Country @IFESNigeria

10. I also extend my appreciation to our donors; the United States Agency for International Development (USAID), and the Foreign, Commonwealth, and Development Office (FCDO) for their continuous support and commitment to enhancing credible elections in Nigeria.

9. I would like to appreciate all stakeholders present here for their participation in this important dialogue which highlights our collective willingness to work together to ensure that Nigeria‚Äôs electoral process is truly inclusive of the needs and aspirations of women.

8. With the support of the IFES, INEC organized this discussion to raise the voices of women in public life, understand their problems & get their opinions in light of the upcoming 2023 elections in an effort to uphold this principle & give women a level playing field in politics
7. The participation of men and women equally in all aspects of public life is one of the essential pillars of democracy.

6. Here in Nigeria, we can point to many examples of the powerful effects of women uniting for a common cause, such as the ongoing mobilization of women across party lines to develop plans to end the persistent underrepresentation of women in elected political office.
5. Women's movements have led the way in establishing relevant legislation and policies for gender equality and boosting women's involvement in local, national, and international affairs.

4. The results of this support have been overwhelmingly good, and it has helped the commission hold elections that can be trusted. @IFESNigeria would like to thank INEC for its cooperation, openness to receiving assistance, and overall generosity over the past few years.

3. @IFESNigeria has provided INEC with technical support in important areas like strategic planning, election project plans, electoral operations, the inclusion of marginalized groups, and technical training on essential electoral thematic areas.

2. I applaud the Commission for bringing this crucial conversation to Nigerian women & by extension, the Gender & Inclusivity department. I want to extend my congratulations to all the candidates & women's organizations who worked together to make this national dialogue a reality

On behalf of the International Foundation for Electoral Systems (@IFESNigeria), I am pleased to join you at this National Dialogue for Women Groups and Candidates Ahead of the 2023 General Elections. https://t.co/07S7R3JmBy

13. May I at this point, appreciate our Development Partner, @IFESNigeria, for supporting this engagement. This enduring partnership, we believe will continue to yield good results in governance.I wish you all a fruitful deliberationLakunuya BelloDirector Gender & Inclusivity
12. I therefore urge you to participate actively in the dialogue towards charting a new course for increased women participation in the 2023 General Election and beyond.

11. Recent Voter Registration statistics for the 2023 General Election, released by the Commission, indicates that of the 93,469,008 registered voters, 47.5% are women. This is a huge voting community, a number which if strategically deployed, can determine the election outcome.

10. For us in the Commission, we have taken the lead to incorporate gender issues in the electoral process. The degree to which women's participation in politics can strongly influence policies and programs of government, lies to a large extent, with them.

9. Today in this hall, stakeholders comprising women professional bodies, women political activists and women scholars have gathered to dialogue and find ways to increase women participation in the 2023 General Election.

8. We are interested in engaging them in active politics to enrich our electoral system. This has become imperative considering the sharp decrease in the number of women who won elective positions in 2019 General Elections.

7. Women population is almost half of the country's population. The Commission with the collaboration of stakeholders in the electoral process has adopted strategies to reach these women, to ensure that they are actively involved in the electoral process.

6. I wish to mention that from the election in 2015, the Commission has improved its processes and procedures to ensure that gender is adequately mainstreamed in the electoral process, and this is reflected in its activities in the 2019 General Election.
5. Women in Nigeria are assured of a supportive environment to participate in the electoral process in any capacity, degree or role they may choose.
4. Nigeria having signed a significant number of international and regional protocols and conventions that guarantee the protection of women's rights to political participation.
3. INEC is committed to seeing that Nigeria's Political landscape is and will continue to provide a level playing field for participation of all citizens in the electoral process.

2. Again, nation states where men and women are involved in decision making at all levels tend to develop better and faster than those that do not make deliberate efforts to protect the interest of all citizens, irrespective of Gender.

The Commission has continually demonstrated its willingness to engage with all stakeholders in the discharge of its duties realizing that equal participation of women and men in all aspects of public life is a key principle of democracy. https://t.co/T4rPMsUQI9

20. Finally, once again, I commend @IFESNigeria for collaborating with INEC and working tirelessly towards promoting a vibrant electoral process in Nigeria.I thank you all and God bless.Prof. Kunle AjayiNational Commissioner and Chairman OPC

18. On this note I would like to encourage everybody here present to please contribute to the discourse and proffer actionable strategies to improve the PVC collection rate and devise strategies to ensure we have improved number of female voters in the coming general election.

17. It is my belief that the Nigerian women have so much to contribute to the socio-political and economic landscape of the Nigeria, that they simply have to hold their rightful position at the helms of affairs of our great country.

16. Yesterday, we had a workshop with the Gender Desk Officers of the various security agents, where they were trained on various strategies to mitigate against women voters intimidation. So, please we urge you all to come out to exercise ur franchise without fear on election day
15. The Commission, through its Outreach and Partnership Committee, has been very intentional in all its gender engagements to speak up against violence against women in elections.
14. Beyond PVC collection, the final task is for the Nigerian women to show up on election day and exercise their franchise by voting for a candidate of their choice.
13. We should also utilize the window of opportunity provided by the Commission to collect our PVCs by extending the deadline by one week.

12. However, you still need to show up and play your part in the collection process. The Commission is appealing to you all to please do not wait till the last minute before you show up at the designated centres to collect your PVCs.
11. The Commission has deployed a Standard Operating Procedure to ensure a seamless collection process, and provisions have been made for States that prefer separate queues for men and women.

10. The journey to women power and equality starts with very intentional and committed efforts in going out to get your PVCs. The same enthusiasm and zeal that was used to register, must be tapped into to ensure commensurate number of PVC collection.

9. This indeed is a herculean task, but, with the power of your PVC and the opportunity of the coming elections, there is an avenue for women to change the narrative, speak with a united voice and grasp the mantle of leadership in their favour.
8. However, to translate these data into actual reality and voting force, the Nigerian women need to rise above all socio-economic and political factors militating against them.
7. By implication, this means that the Nigerian women are a major power block and a voting force to contend with in the forthcoming general elections.

6. According to the CVR report by INEC, the total registered number of voters for the 2023 General Election stands at 93,469,008 out of which women voters constitute 44,414846 or 48%, while the men constitute 49,054162 or 52% & the youths (18-35) constitute 37,060,399 0r 40%.
5. Similarly, in terms of electoral strength and voting population, there are almost as many women registered voters as men.
4. Out of this figure the number of men totaled; 108,652,797 while the female numbers totaled 105,915,930. i.e. the current percentage of men in Nigeria is 50.6% while that of women is 49.4%.
3. Indeed, it is a known fact that the population of Nigerian women is as large as that of the men. According to Country Meters, the current population of Nigerians stands at 218,017,934.

2. Please, allow me to thank the organizers of this program, the International Foundation for Electoral Support (@IFESNigeria) for sponsoring this National Dialogue at this very crucial point in the timeline of the elections.

It gives me immense pleasure to welcome you all to this very important National Dialogue on Women‚Äôs Participation In PVC Collection & Election Day Processes  ahead of the 2023 General Election which is just 37 days away.@IFESNigeria https://t.co/mffbahzRdq

27. In particular, we appreciate your collective and individual sacrifice to ensure that election personnel and materials arrive at designated locations early, especially during the recent Ekiti and Osun State Governorship elections.
26. I want to place on record, our appreciation of the commitment of the Unions to our electoral processes and the consolidation of our democracy.

25. The Unions should keep an eye on your members to ensure that when they take personnel and materials to designated locations, they also bring them back at the end of the elections. Your contract is for both forward and reverse logistics.

24. They must see their role as a national call to duty by ensuring that there is no failure on their part, especially on the eve of elections when it is too late for the Commission to make alternative arrangements.
23. Learning from the experience of the past, I would like to appeal to all the Unions and service providers to abide by the spirit and letter of the MoU and the contract agreements respectively.
22. As usual, we shall track the movement of all vehicles and boats electronically and in real time to ensure that election personnel and materials are not hijacked or diverted.
21. The security agencies shall not only be available to escort all vehicles and boats to locations, they will also ensure the safety and protection of all election personnel and materials.

20. We will therefore require your members to swear and strictly adhere to this oath and the INEC Code of Conduct for Electoral Officials as your participation in the delivery of electoral logistics requires absolute neutrality and non-partisanship.
19. A new requirement in the new electoral legal framework is that everyone involved in election duties must subscribe to the INEC Oath/Affirmation of Neutrality.

18. In doing so, you will be required to work very closely with our RECs & collaborate with the Federal Regulatory & Safety Agencies to ensure that the objectives of the MoU are fully realised in terms of required road/sea worthiness & safety standards of your vehicles and boats.
17. It is our expectation that the leadership of the unions will effectively supervise their members in the various chapters and branches for the full implementation of the MoU.

14. The agreement which is legally binding will be based on the actual breakdown of the number of vehicles, tricycles, motorcycles, boats and canoes per State.

13. The Memorandum of Understanding  we are about to sign today is a general framework. The contractual agreement between the Commission and the actual service providers will be worked out at the State & LGA level between officials of the Unions & our RECss and Electoral Officers
12. This oversight is now addressed by the revised MoU to include MWUN comprising of sailors, dockworkers and those in related trades in our electoral logistics planning and delivery.

11. However, we did not incorporate the Maritime Workers Union of Nigeria (MWUN) within the ambit of the MoU, a situation which has often resulted in logistics nightmares in the deployment and retrieval of personnel and materials to the riverine areas of the country.
10. Over the years, the Commission has come to rely on the partnership with the NURTW and NARTO to provide vehicles for the successful deployment of electoral personnel and materials.

9. It was for this reason that the Commission signed the first MoU with the NURTW in January 2015. In order to expand the pool of our service providers to meet the requirement for the increasing number of vehicles, the MoU was reviewed in December 2018 to incorporate NARTO.

8. In order to ensure that personnel and materials will be at the polling units on Election Day awaiting the arrival of voters rather than the other way round, INEC requires large numbers of vehicles, including motorcycles, tricycles, boats and canoes

7. Let me assure Nigerians that we are determined that all polling units nationwide will open at 8.30am on Saturday, 25th February 2023 for the Presidential & National Assembly elections and on Saturday, 11th March 2023 for the Governorship and State House of Assembly elections.

6. It will require over 100,000 vehicles and about 4,200 boats that will be accompanied by naval gunboats. This is a huge undertaking that must be accomplished in the next 66 days and we are resolute in doing so to give Nigerians a pleasant voting experience.

5. The 2023 General Election will involve the nationwide deployment of over 1 million personnel & massive quantities of materials twice within a period of two weeks from our State offices to 774 LGA, 8,809 electoral Wards & 176,846 PUs across the length & breadth of our country.

4. The signing of a revised MoU with the road and marine transport unions today is a demonstration of our determination to implement key recommendations of the review exercise in order to enhance forward and reverse logistics in our electoral operations.

9. The Framework proposes 9 Key Implementation Elements and Timelines that need to be addressed for the successful management of the Commissions logistics processes in the conduct of elections.

8. This framework can serve as a broad guide towards the formulation of a Commission's Electoral Logistics Policy whose timelines and principle elements can be adapted to the type of election under consideration: general, off-cycle or bye-election.
This presentation provides a broad logistics framework based on the recommendations of a 3-Day Expert Meeting on Electoral Logistics for the 2023 General Election.

7. The conduct of elections therefore depends on how well we plan and execute a logistics plan. And a logistics plan must be driven by a framework that properly identifies the key elements that are of critical concern to the Commission in the conduct and management of elections.

5. In addition, a number of these critical services such as transportation, security, and the manning of polling and collation locations depends on officials outside the Commission.

4. It is time bound because personnel and election materials have to be recruited/procured, trained, stored, secured, deployed and retrieved from 176, 846 PUs, 8809 Wards, 774 LGAs, and 36 States plus the FCT.

19. I want to reassure Nigerians that we will recover from these attacks. The lost materials will be replaced but there is a limit to our ability to keep replacing wantonly destroyed materials with just 86 days to the General Election.

18. In these mindless attacks, a total of 1,993 ballot boxes, 399 voting cubicles, 22 electric power generators and thousands of uncollected PVCs were, among other materials, destroyed. These attacks must stop and the perpetrators apprehended and prosecuted.

17. Buildings have been destroyed and materials lost in Udenu and Igboeze North Local Areas of Enugu State, Abeokuta South Local Government of Ogun State, Ede South Local Government Area of Osun State and, most recently, in Izzi Local Government Area of Ebonyi State.

16. Secondly, I wish to once again touch on the troubling issue of attacks on our facilities and the destruction of critical electoral assets in the country. In the last four months, five Local Government Area offices of the Commission were attacked by yet unknown persons.
15. Therefore, the position of the law is clear. The PVC remains a mandatory requirement for voting during elections.

14. For the avoidance of doubt, Section 47(1) of the Electoral Act 2022 provides that "a person intending to vote in an election shall present himself with his voter‚Äôs card to a Presiding Officer for accreditation at the PU in the constituency in which his name is registered".
13. Nothing has changed. It is a legal requirement and doing otherwise will be a violation of the law. I appeal to Nigerians to ignore any suggestion to the contrary.

12. For any person to vote in any election organised by the Commission, he/she must be a registered voter issued with a PVC. The Commission has consistently maintained the policy of "no PVC, no voting".

11. On this note, let me seize this opportunity to comment on two issues. First, is the misleading statement shared online that voters can vote on Election Day without the voter‚Äôs card. This is absolutely incorrect.

10. It has no candidates in the forthcoming election. All political parties have equal standing before the Commission. The choice belongs to Nigerian citizens i.e. the electorate. Our responsibility is to uphold the sanctity of the ballot - nothing more nothing less.

9. Let me therefore reiterate what I recently told you at your swearing-in as Resident Electoral Commissioners. Our success ultimately depends on our integrity. We should remain independent and impartial. As I said on many occasions, the Commission is not a political party.

Datetime: Thank you for your attention.Prof. Mahmood YakubuINEC Chairman

Text: https://t.co/44pyxxnXYZ Lord the Chief Justice of Nigeria, distinguished ladies and gentlemen, I wish you successful deliberations and God‚Äôs infinite wisdom and blessings. The job of the politician is intensely partisan.

26. Before I conclude my remarks, may I acknowledge the support of all our development partners in supporting this capacity-building workshop in particular and deepening the democratic processes in Nigeria.

25. The matter is currently being litigated again, possibly all the way back to the Supreme Court, thereby wasting the precious time of the Courts which are already inundated by even the most improbable cases by litigation-happy individuals and parties.
(and affirmed by the same Court following an application for clarification) put the Commission in a difficult situation.

25. A situation where a trial Court sought to vary the judgement of the Supreme Court by ordering the Commission to issue a Certificate of Return in favour of a candidate whose emergence during the party‚Äôs primary election has been nullified by the apex Court
24. I wish to reassure the judiciary that the Commission will continue to abide by Court orders. However, strict adherence to stare decisis is critical for us as an Election Management Body.
23. It also means that the Courts will be dealing with the same issues long after the General Election.

22. Some of the cases will go up to the Supreme Court. The implication is that we are still dealing with issues of nomination of candidates thereby eating into vital rime for preparation of and procurement of sensitive materials for the materials.

One political party served about 70 Court processes on the Commission in one day seeking to compel us to accept the nomination or substitution of its candidates long after the deadline provided in the Timetable & Schedule of Activities for the 2023 General Election had elapsed.
21. So far, we have been joined in about 600 cases relating to the conduct of recent primaries and nomination of candidates by political parties for the 2023 General Election. Only two weeks ago,

20. As a result, we are witnessing increasingly less Court cases challenging the conduct of elections by the Commission. However, cases arising from the conduct of primaries for the nomination of candidates by political parties is on the increase.

19. We have studied the judgements of the Tribunals arising from both the 2019 General Election, the off-cycle Governorship elections and the bye-elections conducted so far. We identified areas where we need to do more to reduce litigations.
18. Even so, in 23 out of 30 constituencies (i.e. 76%) the elections were only set aside in some polling units and not the wholesale nullification of elections in entire constituencies.
17. For instance, 30 elections were upturned by the Tribunals in 2019 as against over 100 in a previous election.

16. As a consequence of a similar workshop organised ahead of the 2019 General Election, we noticed a sharp reduction in the number of cases arising from that election and consequently a reduced number of elections nullified by the Election Petition Tribunals.
15. We are reassured by the inspiring speech by My Lord the President of the Court of Appeal for the elaborate steps taken against conflicting judgement by Courts of coordinate jurisdiction.
14. abuse of court process and reduction in the spate of conflicting judgements by courts of coordinate jurisdiction.

13. Similarly, the new Electoral Act confers exclusive jurisdiction to hear pre-election cases on the Federal High Court with regard to candidate nomination in order to reduce forum shopping by litigants,
12. and the extension of timelines for the nomination of candidates and for other electoral activities.

11. The new Electoral Act contains eighty new provisions intended to improve our elections and address some of the lacunae in the repealed Electoral Act 2010 (as amended), provide legal backing to the technological innovations introduced by the Commission overtime

10. I have no doubt that this workshop will enhance the understanding of INEC‚Äôs processes, especially the innovations introduced pursuant to the enactment of the Electoral Act 2022 which came into force on 25th February 2022.
9. There will also be an interactive, experience-sharing session on pertinent issues in the determination of election disputes presided over by the Honourable President of the Court of Appeal.
8. Over the next four days, ten papers will be presented and discussed by eminent jurists, lawyers and election experts.
7. Most significantly, it is the first General Election since the repeal of the Electoral Act 2010 (as amended) and its re-enactment as the Electoral Act 2022.

6. The Election will be held in 1,491 constituencies made up of 1 Presidential Constituency, 28 Governorship elections, 109 Senatorial Districts, 360 Federal Constituencies (House of Representatives) and 993 State Constituencies (State House of Assembly).

5. This workshop could not have come at a better time. It is exactly 109 days to the 2023 General Election holding in two phases: national elections (Presidential & Nat. Assembly holding on 25th February 2023) & State elections (Gov. & State Assembly holding on 11th March 2023).

4. Let me therefore express our profound appreciation to the Chief Justice of Nigeria, Hon. Justice Olukayode Ariwoola GCON, and other heads of courts for the sustained collaboration with the Commission.
3. I am glad that the judiciary and the Commission are once again collaborating on the eve of the forthcoming General Election.

2. The workshop in no small measure led to a better appreciation of the electoral processes, reduction in the spate of conflicting judgements as well as consequential reduction in the number of elections nullified and/or overturned after the election.

1. It is my great pleasure to once again be part of this capacity-building workshop. Some of you here may recall that prior to 2019 General Election, a similar workshop was held in which the Commission interacted with the judiciary on the adjudication of post-election disputes.

‚úìAbility to work under pressure is important, because considerable pressure is built into election work.‚úìPressure, whether external or internal, is one of the fertile sources of irregularities in electoral work.

‚úìBe polite and non-confrontational, but consistent and steadfast.‚úìBeing human, you may make a genuine mistake, but never wilfully do wrong.‚úìPlan your work well.‚úìOne important characteristic of a good election official is the ability to ward off negative external pressures

‚úì Ask for advice or direction from your superiors whenever in doubt as to what to do.‚úìExplain matters as fully as you can and cite approved policies, rules, and regulations to support your stand.‚úìGive or obtain documentary evidence for major actions and decisions.

‚úì Be seen to operate in the spirit of openness, to be transparent and fair, in dealing with all stakeholders.‚úì Apply rules, regulations, and procedures evenly without varying them to the advantage/disadvantage of any person or group.

24. We will continue to work round the clock, including the weekends, to ensure that we attend to all applications received at the headquarters of the Commission promptly.Once again, I welcome you all to this meeting. I thank you and God bless.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu
23. Indeed, there are now far more cases challenging the breach of internal democracy within political parties than those involving the conduct of the main elections by INEC.

22. As at yesterday evening (Friday 1st July 2022), 216 requests have so far been processed involving the certification of over One Million Six Hundred and Fifty Thousand (1,650,000) pages of documents.

21. that all requests are being attended to expeditiously despite the huge quantities of documents involved. Nigerian elections, especially the conduct of primaries for the nomination of candidates by political parties, is one of the most litigated in the world.

20. Before I conclude, let me seize this opportunity to once again reassure all Nigerians who applied for Certified True Copies (CTCs) of documents arising from the recent party congresses, primaries and nomination of candidates‚Ä¶
19. I appeal to all security agencies to continue to join hands with the Commission to tackle this menace.

18. In particular, we are working with the Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC) to ensure the prosecution of persons arrested in the recent Ekiti Governorship election. Action will commence as soon as the EFCC completes its investigation.

17. Again, arising from the experience in recent elections, vote buying remains a major area of concern. We appreciate the role played by the anti-corruption and security agencies in apprehending some of the perpetrators of this brazen assault on our democracy.
16. The BVAS biometric accreditation will expose such fraud and persons apprehended will be prosecuted under the law.

15. I would like to assure all valid registrants in Osun State that no one will be disenfranchised on account of such incident. It is futile for anyone to attempt to vote using another person‚Äôs PVC.
14. Meanwhile, the State office has compiled the Voter Identification Numbers (VINs) of the cards and the Commission has already reprinted the PVCs for the affected voters.
13. While the matter is being investigated by the police, the collection of PVCs for the affected Wards is now taking place in the INEC office in Ijebu-Jesha.
12. In one recent example, the collection of Permanent Voters Cards (PVCs) was disrupted in Erin Oke and Erin Ijesha Wards of Oriade Local Government Area resulting in the loss of 46 PVCs.

11. Arising from the experience of the recent Ekiti State Governorship election, the Commission is keeping a close watch on the security situation in Osun State. Although it is generally calm at the moment, we are nevertheless concerned about reports of clashes in some places.

10. A few days to the election, we will return to Osun State to meet with the stakeholders and for the signing of the Peace Accord by political parties and candidates under the auspices of the National Peace Committee.

9. We will also observe the mock accreditation of voters in some Polling Units across the three Senatorial Districts of the State to test the functionality of the Bimodal Voter Accreditation System (BVAS).

8. We will visit some of our Local Government offices in the State, hold meetings with our staff, brief the Council of Traditional rulers to solicit the support of their Royal Majesties for peaceful elections and meet with the security agencies and transporters.

7. On our part, all the major activities that are supposed to be carried out at this stage have been successfully undertaken. The Commission is deploying a readiness assessment team to Osun State next week to assess our preparations for the elections.

6. At this meeting, the Resident Electoral Commissioner (REC) and the Commissioner of Police (CP) will brief us on the state of readiness for the election. I am glad to welcome the REC for Osun State, Professor Abdulganiy Olayinka Raji, and the CP, Wale Olokode, to this meeting.

5. In the next two weeks, the Osun State Governorship election is holding on Saturday 16th July 2022. As is the case on the eve of all major off-cycle Governorship elections, ICCES holds a special meeting to review operational and deployment plans.

4. I must, on behalf of the Commission, convey our appreciation to all members of ICCES for the success of the election. We must continue to build on the success of the Ekiti experience to ensure improved performance in subsequent elections, including the 2023 General Election.

3. The election was peaceful. Personnel and materials were deployed promptly. Election Day processes commenced as scheduled. Election technology functioned optimally. Results were transmitted from the Polling Units and collated at the various collation centres in record time.

2. The synergy between the Commission and the security agencies on the one hand, and among the security agencies on the other, ensured a seamless coordination of efforts resulting in the widely acclaimed success of the election. Security was well-coordinated.

1. I warmly welcome you to this special meeting. This is coming barely four weeks after a similar meeting on 3rd June 2022 to review the security arrangement for the recently concluded Ekiti State Governorship election.

13. This will be your own way of showing commitment to the Peace Accord and appreciation for the work of the Peace Committee.I thank you and may God bless the efforts of the National Peace Committee.

12. The truth is that the Peace Accord is not an automated, self-actualising process. Let me therefore call on all political parties & candidates to abide by the letter & spirit of the Accord by appealing to ur supporters to maintain peace before, during and after the elections.

11. Working for the last 12 months since June 2021 when we released the Timetable for the #EkitiDecides2022 election, it is inconceivable that INEC will undermine itself, especially on Election Day & beyond. I want to assure you all that the votes of the Ekiti people will count.

10. The success of the Peace Accord rests on three pedestals: the political actors, INEC and security agencies. Speaking for INEC, I wish to assure the Peace Committee of our commitment to transparent and credible elections.

9. and, ultimately, the credibility of elections will be undermined. No credible election can be achieved in an atmosphere of disruption, violence and disorder. It is, therefore, important for everyone to maintain the peace.

8. I urge parties and candidates in Ekiti State to realise that without peace, our deployment plans; new innovations in voter accreditation and result management; the safety of voters, election duty staff, observers and the journalists; security of materials;

7. Working with civil society organisations, the media, security agencies, traditional and religious institutions, and other stakeholders, INEC will continue to partner with the Peace Committee for peaceful elections in Nigeria.

5. The intervention of the Peace Committee no doubt contributed in no small way to the peaceful conduct of previous Governorship elections. We are confident that the Ekiti State Governorship election holding this Saturday will not be different.

4. Since the Edo State Gov. election held in September 2020, followed by the Ondo State Gov. election in October 2020 & the Anambra State Gov. election in November 2021, political parties & candidates have signed the Peace Accord under the auspices of the National Peace Committee

3. Today, we are honoured by the presence of the Convener of the NPC, Bishop Matthew Hassan Kukah. By its consistent engagement, the NPC has demonstrated that moral suasion is as important as statutory authority in promoting peace in our country.

2. for convening this meeting. We are forever grateful to the respected statesmen, traditional, religious and business leaders who are working in a voluntary and non-partisan way to promote peaceful elections in Nigeria.

1. On behalf of the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC), I would like to express our profound appreciation to the National Peace Committee (NPC) under the leadership of our respected former Head of State, His Excellency General Abdulsalami A. Abubakar GCFR,

24. The Commission continues to deploy technology in the electoral process both as a matter of practice and a requirement of the law.

23. Similarly, our revised Regulations and Guidelines provide for priority to be accorded at polling units to PwDs without waiting in long queues during voting as is the case with elderly people, pregnant women and nursing mothers.

21. To underscore our commitment to an inclusive, credible and transparent electoral process, the Commission is deploying a number of assistive devices for Persons with Disabilities (PwDs) to have a more pleasant voting experience on Election Day.
20. I appeal to all registered voters that are yet to collect the PVCs to seize the opportunity to do so.

19. In response to these enquiries, I wish to announce that the collection of PVCs will continue in all our 16 Local Government Area Offices until Thursday16th June 2022 to allow us one day (i.e. Friday 17th June 2022) for movement to the Registration Area Centres.

18. However, in the last few days, the Commission has received several inquiries from citizens who are yet to collect their PVCs and are demanding to know when the collection of cards will be suspended before the election.

17. I am happy to note that many citizens have already collected their cards. Of the 988,923 registered voters in Ekiti State, 749,065 (or 76%) have collected their cards as at yesterday Monday 13th June 2022.

16. Voter registration was carried out all over the State, including the devolution of the exercise to the 177 Wards across the State. We have printed and delivered the PVCs for all valid registrants in Ekiti State and collection of the cards by voters is ongoing.

15. For a more effective supervision of the process, we have deployed four National Commissioners, eight Resident Electoral Commissioners and many senior officials to support our State office here in Ekiti State to deliver credible elections.
14. We have made arrangements for the transportation of personnel and materials to all polling units on Election Day.

13. We have recruited, trained and carefully screened all categories of ad-hoc staff to be deployed to the field. We have delivered all non-sensitive materials for the election. Voter education and sensitisation is ongoing.

12. We had several engagements with the security agencies at national, State and Local Government levels. We consulted with stakeholders. We sought for, and received, the blessings of Royal Fathers and religious leaders.

11. So far, the Commission has implemented several activities for the election. We have taken every step and made every arrangement for the successful conduct of the Governorship election this weekend. We held many meetings with political parties and their candidates.

10. It is also the first election to be conducted based on our revised Regulations & Guidelines anchored on the provisions of the new Electoral Act. We have also revised our Training Manual to reflect the provisions of the new Electoral Act as well as the Regulations & Guidelines

9. In this regard, the election holding this weekend is historic being the first Governorship election that the Commission will be conducting based on the provisions of the Electoral Act 2022 which came into force about four months ago on 25th February 2022.
8. Our focus is on the processes and procedures as provided by law.

7. For us in INEC, let me reassure political parties, candidates & the electorate that the choice of who becomes the next Governor of Ekiti State is entirely in the hands of voters. INEC will not take any action to the advantage or disadvantage of any political party or candidate

6. I am also glad that the Inspector General of Police, as the head of the lead agency in internal security, is personally here today to address the triple dimensions of securing the process before, during and after the elections.
5. We are taking both issues very seriously. I will speak about our preparations for free, fair, credible, transparent and inclusive election.

4. The Commission is aware that stakeholders have expressed concerns about the election and would like to be given assurances in two critical areas. First is the transparency and credibility of the election; and secondly, its security and peaceful conduct.

3. The Governorship election will be combined with a pending bye-election in Ekiti East I State House of Assembly constituency which was earlier suspended following the unfortunate disruption of the process in March last year.

2. As you are all aware, the Governorship election in Ekiti State will hold this Saturday after several months of preparations since the Commission released the Timetable and Schedule of Activities in June last year.

41. I thank you all for your presence and God bless.Prof. Mahmood YakubuINEC Chairman
40. I wish to reassure you that the Commission has taken every step to ensure that the election this weekend is free, fair, credible, inclusive and safe.

39. The occasion is holding in this hall at 10am tomorrow Wednesday 15th June 2022. On this note, let me once again welcome the Inspector-General of Police, leaders and candidates of political parties, and all other stakeholders to this meeting.

38. Before I conclude, I would like to seize this opportunity to invite you all to the signing of the Peace Accord by parties and candidates under the auspices of the National Peace Committee chaired by our respected former Head of State, General Abdulsalami Abubakar GCFR.

37. We have also intensified our collaboration with the Economic & Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC) and the Independent Corrupt Practices Commission to deal with both the buyers & the takers under the law. I urge all stakeholders to join the Commission in tackling the menace.

36. To discourage the practice, we changed the configuration of our polling units to bring the ballot boxes closer to the voting cubicles and also banned the use of mobile phones and photographic devices by voters while in the voting cubicles.
35. Like every conscientious Nigerian, the Commission is deeply worried by the use of money to induce voters on Election Day. Clearly, vote buying is a threat to our electoral democracy.

34. At the same time, citizens can contact us on our various platforms such as the toll-free INEC Citizens Contact Centre (ICCC) telephone line in addition to our Twitter, Facebook and Instagram accounts.
33. We are working to ensure that accredited observers and the media are invited to join us at intervals to provide live reports from the field.
32. On Election Day, the national headquarters of INEC in Abuja will monitor the election throughout the State. Our Zoom Situation Room will be activated.
31. Similarly, 483 journalists representing 91 media organisation were accredited to cover the election as at yesterday afternoon.

30. As a testimony to the intense national and international interest in the 2022 Ekiti State Governorship Election, 87 observer groups (79 domestic and 8 international) have been accredited to observe the election.

29. The Commission has accredited Polling Agents nominated by political parties for all the 2,445 polling units, 177 Ward collation centres, 16 Local Government Area collation centres and the State Collation Centre where the final declaration of result will be made.

28. We are encouraged by the successful outcome of the exercise. We have also trained enough Registration Area Technical Support (RATECHs) staff and made adequate transportation arrangements for their rapid response in the event of reported glitches on Election Day.

27. A few weeks ago, mock accreditation exercise was conducted in polling units across the three Senatorial Districts of Ekiti State. I personally observed the mock exercise in Ado, Ikere and Irepodun/Ifelodun Local Government Areas.
26. Steps have been taken to ensure that the BVAS machines function optimally during voter accreditation based on lessons learnt from the conduct of recent elections.

25. The Bimodal Voter Accreditation System (BVAS) will be deployed for voter accreditation and uploading of election results to the INEC Result Viewing (IReV) portal on Election Day. The devices have already been configured and charged for the election.

k) All holders of power at all levels shall refrain from acts of intimidation or harassment against defeated candidates or their supporters.

j) The party and/or candidate who lose the elections shall concede defeat to the political party and/or candidate finally declared the winner, following the guidelines and within the deadline stipulated by the law.

i) Member States shall use the services of civil society organisations involved in electoral matters to educate and enlighten the public on the need for peaceful elections devoid of all acts of violence.
h) Adequate arrangements shall be made to hear and dispose of all petitions relating to the conduct of elections and announcement of results.
g) The preparation and conduct of elections and the announcement of results shall be done in a transparent manner.
f) The voters‚Äô lists shall be prepared in a transparent and reliable manner, with the collaboration of the political parties and voters who may have access to them whenever the need arises.
‚Ä¶ Member States shall cooperate in this area with a view to exchanging experiences and where necessary providing technical assistance to each other in the production of reliable voters‚Äô lists.
e) 5. Each ECOWAS Member State shall ensure the establishment of a reliable registry of births and deaths. A central registry shall be established in each Member State.

d) The bodies responsible for organising the elections shall be independent or neutral and shall have the confidence of all the political actors. Where necessary, appropriate national consultations shall be organised to determine the nature and the structure of the bodies.
‚Ä¶ and the implementation thereof & to hold public offices & perform public functions at all levels of governance.
c) Member States shall take all appropriate measures to ensure that women have equal rights with men to vote & be voted for in elections, to participate in the formulation of government policies‚Ä¶

a)No substantial modification shall be made to the electoral laws in the last 6 months before the elections, except with the consent of a majority of political actorsb)All the elections shall be organised on the dates or at periods fixed by the Constitution or the electoral laws
12. The ECOWAS Protocol underlined some benchmarks for the assessment of Elections in West Africa. They include the following:
11. lists conditions that must exist for a free expression of will by the electors and for results of the elections to reflect the wishes of the people.

10. The African Charter on Democracy, Elections and Governance and the ECOWAS Protocol A/SP1/12/01 on Democracy and Good Governance Supplementary to the Protocol relating to the Mechanism for Conflict Prevention, Management, Resolution, Peacekeeping and Security
9. the African Union (AU) and the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) have developed some benchmarks for assessing elections in Africa and the West African sub region.

7. The Standards for Free and Fair Elections. Although the actual indices and ingredients for measuring free and fair election is still a subject of contestation, there are irreducible minimums for measuring the fairness and freeness of an election.

6. the role of civil society groups and organizations in holding the different organs and agencies of government accountable; the existence of a fair and speedy adjudicatory system for the resolution of electoral disputes and many more.

5. the internal democratic practices and processes of the political parties; the freedom allowed the media to operate and hold a balance between all competing political parties; the role that will be played by the security agencies in the election;

4. These include the constitutive legal instruments and regime that will be used in the conduct of the election; the political, economic and social context for the election; the extent of preparedness of the independent National Electoral Commission;

3. As the people of Ekiti State prepare for the conduct of the Governorship election scheduled to hold on the 18th day of June 2022 & as the build up to the 2023 general election gathers momentum, certain variables will shape and determine the context & content of the elections.

2. The media continues to monitor & report on the activities of the different arms of government, criticizing & sometimes offering & proffering different approaches and strategies to governance as well as educating & sensitizing the citizens on their rights and responsibilities.
1. The media has been a constant and central player in the electoral and democratic processes of the country. The media has played and continues to play the role of holding governments accountable.

18. INEC will continue to engage with critical stakeholders at various levels to secure support in incorporating gender issues into the electoral process in Nigeria. The Commission is committed to upholding and giving the required leadership to achieve this.

17. The Policy which is a living document is expected to foster gender balance in the Commission and to stimulate stakeholders in the electoral process to do the same. It was revised to codify the Commission's gender sensitive actions for sustainable implementation.
16. Several review meetings (virtual and in-person) were held with Civil Society Organisations (CSOs), and internally with Commission members and internally with Commission members and staff.
15. The INEC Gender Policy with its implementation framework had a lifespan of 4 years but due to the exigencies of the 2019 General Elections, the review was conducted in 2020.
14. Supporting an enabling legislative environment to achieve gender equality and bridging gaps in political representation in elective posts at all electoral levels.
13. Increasing budgetary provisions and mobilizing partners to effectively provide funding for gender sensitive actions within their purview.

12. The Policy has four principal objectives: Ensuring that INEC Policies, plans, process & operations are gender responsive.Encouraging gender equality& balance within political parties especially in the identification of candidates in line with the provisions of their statutes

11. The Commission in 2014 introduced the INEC Gender Policy along with its implementation framework as a response to the National Gender Policy (2006) which calls on all state and non-state actors to promote gender through their institutional practices and policies.

10. INEC as Nigeria's National EMB is committed to providing a level playing field for all stakeholders in the electoral process. It recognizes the place of gender equality in the credibility checklist for the management and administration of electoral processes.

9. In the course discharging this duty, the Election Management Body is expected to adopt procedures that align with the constitutional principles of social justice, equality and equity in a bid to eliminate discrimination and foster inclusiveness in the electoral process.

8. One of most important roles of Election: Management body in democracy is provide an enabling environment for all citizens irrespective of gender, exercise their constitutional rights and privileges to vote and voted for during elections.

7. The Commission sees the issues gender equality and women‚Äôs empowerment as priority agenda, hence commitment to deepen and consolidate Nigeria‚Äôs democracy. The Commission has also resolved foster gender mainstreaming all aspects of the electoral process.
6. In line international best practices, INEC committed facilitating electoral process that both gender responsive and reference point as Election Management Body (EMB) of highest standard.
5. These roles clearly encapsulated in INEC Gender Policy which Division has responsibility implementing.

4. The core mandate of the Gender Relations Division of the Gender and Inclusivity Department is to spearhead the mainstreaming of gender in the Commission's structure, policy and operations; and also to promote genderresponsiveness in electoral process general.
3. We have come to realize that democracies globally that practice inclusiveness in the electoral process develop faster than those that do not.
2. Consequently, electoral systems around the world are constantly looking for ways to reduce marginalization in the election management process.

1. Gender is fundamental to any democracy. Any perceived imbalance in representation or participation by any segment of society in a democracy undermines the core democratic principles of equity, equality and fairness.

22. Unfortunately, the number of litigations by aggrieved party members challenging the conduct of party primaries so far may exceed the 807 pre-election Court cases on the 2019 General Election in which the Commission was joined by litigants.

21. As you conclude your primaries and prepare for the off-cycle and general elections, I urge you to ensure a transparent electioneering process devoid of acrimony and rancour. In doing so, fidelity to internal democracy is critical.

14. As you conduct your primaries and nominate candidates for elections, this is the appropriate time to remind you of your commitment to promoting inclusivity in the electoral process.

Unveiling of the INEC 2022-2026 Strategic Plan (SP) and the 2023 Election Project Plan (EPP) by the Hon. Chairman INEC, Prof. Mahmood Yakubu, Members of Commission, Resident Electoral Commissioners (RECs), Development Partners and other stakeholders today 21st April 2022 in Abuja https://t.co/nCSHBzIc1e

33. The Commission also appreciates our development partners, especially the @IFES1987 and @ECESeu, for consistently supporting the Commission‚Äôs efforts to deepen electoral integrity and consolidate our democracy.May God continue to bless our effortsProf. Mahmood Yakubu
32. On this note, I would like to thank all stakeholders for honouring our invitation.
31. Anyone engaged in the act of double or multiple registration is liable to prosecution. No citizen should engage in it or encourage others to violate the law.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

30. These steps are in compliance with the law in order to serve Nigerians better. The claim that PVCs expire is misleading. Citizens are therefore advised not to register more than once as multiple registration is an offence under the Electoral Act.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu
28. Similarly, voters who had issues with their accreditation in previous elections have been encouraged to revalidate and update their information.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu
27. We have encouraged those whose lost their voters cards or whose cards are damaged to approach any of the registration centres to apply for replacement.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

26. For emphasis, the Commission once again reiterates that PVCs have no expiry dates. We want to assure all registered voters that PVCs issued by the Commission remain valid for all elections.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

25. Let me also reassure those who registered between January and March 2022 as well as those who are doing so until the end of the exercise that their PVCs will be ready for collection long before the 2023 General Election.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

24. I would like to appeal to all Nigerians who registered between June and December 2021 to collect their Permanent Voters Cards (PVCs) in person as no PVCs will be collected by proxy.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu
23. Furthermore, the PVCs of validly registered voters from the first and second quarters are already available for collection at designated centres nationwide.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

22. The ongoing Continuous Voter registration (CVR) exercise will be end on 30th June 2022 and all eligible voters that are yet to register are advised to do so on or before that date if they intend to vote.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

20. INEC plays a critical role but the Commission alone cannot deliver the elections we all desire. I therefore appeal to all Nigerians to joins hands with us in ensuring that we make a success of the process.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu
19. Clearly, these are challenging times but we are determined that election must hold in 2023. However, this is a shared responsibility.

18. We will continue to engage early and intensely with the security agencies to ensure the safety of our personnel and materials, accredited observers and the media and, above all, the voters.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

‚Ä¶ prompt commencement of polls, availability of assistive devices for persons with disability at polling units and greater transparency in result management. We are also aware of the security challenges and their impact on the electoral process.

17. We have carefully listened to the demand of Nigerians for seamless processes, particularly with regard to enhanced voter education, better distribution of voters to polling units, quality training of election personnel, functionality of electronic devices, improved logistics,

16. Work has also commenced on the review of the manuals for the training of election duty personnel. With the planning processes virtually completed, the Commission will now focus its attention on election technology and election administration.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu
15. By next week, the Commission will conclude the revision of the Regulations and Guidelines for the Conduct of Elections to comply with the provisions of the Electoral Act 2022.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

‚Ä¶ to support the delivery of free, fair, credible and inclusive elections. The Plan also forms the basis for the Election Project Plan which focuses on five key objectives identified by the Commission as critical for the successful conduct of the 2023 General Election.

14. These concerns are reflected in the Plan‚Äôs five strategic objectives, each of which identified several key actions, key activities and key outcomes that constitute a broad guide to the vision of the Commission to provide electoral operations, systems and infrastructure‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶ the promotion of professionalism, encouraging greater synergy among departments, improving efficient utilisation of resources, increased deployment of technology as well as greater sensitivity to threats to the electoral process as well as election personnel and infrastructure

13. Against the backdrop of the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and the current security situation in the country, both plans had to prioritise the institutionalisation of the Commission‚Äôs processes for the effective delivery of its mandate by focusing on capacity-building, ‚Ä¶
12. They build on the successes of the preceding plans, especially in the planning and conduct of the 2019 General Election as well as off-cycle and bye-elections.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu
11. The Strategic Plan 2022-2026 and the 2023 Election Project Plan drew lessons from, and thoroughly reviewed, the level of implementation of the last plans.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

10. Consequently, our elections are getting better, electoral outcomes less contentious, and voter experience of the electoral system increasingly more participatory and inclusive.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

9. Third is the institutionalization of the culture of planning. These elements have guided the Commission through three successive general and several off-cycle and bye elections.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

8. To do this, the Commission relies on three key elements. First is the knowledge and experience gathered from the conduct of previous elections. Second is the use of innovations to enhance electoral integrity and improve voter experience.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

7. The election will be governed by a new Electoral Act 2022, which contains many progressive provisions that will enhance the capacity of the Commission to conduct elections and manage the electoral process better.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

6. The election will involve an estimated one million electoral officials (both permanent and temporary or ad hoc staff) deployed to 176,846 polling units in 8,809 Wards and 774 Local Government Areas across the country.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

5. As you may be aware, the election will be conducted for 1,491 constituencies nationwide made up of 1 presidential constituency, 109 senatorial districts, 360 federal constituencies, 28 governorship elections and 993 state constituencies.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu
4.  I am glad to report that these plans have been finalised ten months ahead of the 2023 General Election.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu
3. The documents presented today are the third in the series of strategic election plans since the era of deliberate planning of elections started in 2012. Prof. Mahmood Yakubu
2. It is my pleasure to welcome you to the official presentation of the INEC Strategic Plan 2022-2026 and the INEC Election Project Plan for the 2023 General Election.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu
