24. Before I conclude, I would like to thank the Development Partners for their support through the International Foundation for Electoral System (IFES) which has greatly facilitated this retreat.Prof. Mahmood YakubuCc: @IFES1987

23. I am glad to report that the Commission has completed the ABIS for the first and second quarter of the CVR. The Commission is meeting next week and the detailed dates and locations for the collection of PVCs will be announced.

22. The reason why we have not made the PVCs available is because of the cleaning up the registration to ensure that only genuine registrants are added to the voters register using the Automated Biometric Identification System (ABIS) for fingerprint and facial clean up.

21. The Commission is aware that new registrants as well as those who applied for transfer or replacement of the Permanent Voters‚Äô Cards (PVCs) would like to know when the cards will be available for collection.
20. Millions of Nigerians have registered so far and we have been giving Weekly updates of the progress of the exercise for the last nine months.

17. The Commission is also working on the distribution of voters to polling units across the country following the successful expansion of voter access to polling units. Very soon, we will roll out the plan for achieving a more balanced distribution of voters to the polling units

16. We received no complaints from voters and no reports of glitches from observers in these bye-elections. We will continue to perfect the system in the forthcoming bye-elections and the end of tenure Gov elections in Ekiti State on 18th June 2022 & Osun State on 16th July 2022.

15. In the recent bye-elections in six constituencies in four States of the Federation across four geo-political zones, the BVAS functioned optimally in rural, sub-urban and urban areas of Cross River, Imo, Ondo and Plateau States.
14. May I also seize this opportunity to reassure Nigerians that we have identified the challenges associated with the Bimodal Voter Accreditation System (BVAS) during voter accreditation.

13. Very soon, we will finalise work on the Regulations and Guidelines for elections taking into consideration the provisions of the Electoral Act 2022. The three documents will be published and presented to the public next month i.e. April 2022.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu@IFES1987

12. My third responsibility is to reassure Nigerians of our commitment to credible polls in 2023. The Commission has concluded work on the Strategic Plan 2022-2026 and Election Project Plan for the 2023 General Election.

11. This retreat is important, especially coming shortly after we released the Timetable and Schedule of Activities for the 2023 General Election in which party primaries are scheduled to commence next week and end in the first week of June i.e. 4th April to 3rd June 2022.
10. our impartiality, dogged adherence to rules, commitment to the sanctity of the ballot and sound knowledge of the electoral process.

9. However, while these innovations and stakeholder engagements are critical to preparations for elections, we should bear in mind that equally critical to the conduct of successful elections is our credibility as election managers:
8. Above all, we need to continuously engage with citizens and stakeholders. Prof. Mahmood YakubuCc: @IFES1987

7. We all therefore stand to learn a lot from this retreat, particularly with the coming into force of the Electoral Act 2022. The Commission has also introduced a number of new innovations that we need to perfect ahead of the General Election.

6. The remaining seven Commissioners are new to the Commission except for ad hoc duties some of them may have performed as collation or returning officers in previous elections or legal representation in election petitions.

5. We now have the full complement of 12 National Commissioners, three of them serving for a second term of five years, one of them elevated from a REC to a National Commissioner, another one a long-serving regular staff of the Commission who has attained the rank of a Director.
4. My second responsibility is to underscore the importance of this retreat, particularly for the Commission members.

3. The expertise of the seven resource persons cut across several areas of theory and practice of democracy, election management, law, human rights, criminal justice reform, electoral reform, election observation and capacity-building for election managers.Cc: @IFES1987
2. In particular, I would like to welcome our distinguished invited guests and to appreciate them for accepting to address us at this retreat.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu@IFES1987

17. The task ahead is challenging. It is important therefore to quickly settle in & familiarize yourselves with the rules, procedures and responsibilities of your office. I have no doubt that we will continue to raise the bar of credible elections in NigeriaProf. Mahmood Yakubu
16. Before I conclude, let me draw the attention of the new National and Resident Electoral Commissioners to the reality of serving in INEC.

15. In addition, we are right now preparing for two off-cycle Governorship elections in Ekiti and Osun States scheduled for 18th June 2022 and 16th July 2022 respectively as well as the 2023 General Election.¬†Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

14. In addition to the six bye-elections holding this weekend, there are three pending bye-elections in Zamfara State (Shinkafi and Gusau I State Constituencies) and Kaduna State (Giwa West State Constituency).Prof. Mahmood Yakubu
13. The reality today is that there is no election season in Nigeria any longer. Elections are conducted all-year round by the Commission.

12. You are coming on board just three days to the conduct of six bye-elections to fill vacancies in three Federal and three State constituencies in Cross River, Imo, Ondo and Plateau States.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

11. In discharging our enormous responsibilities, we must abide by our oaths of office. We must continue to defend the choice made by Nigerians at the polls by protecting the sanctity of the vote without which the value of democratic election is diminished.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

10. We must be strict in the application of the law, firm in handling the public trust bestowed in us and fair in our dealings with political parties, candidates and other stakeholders and all Nigerians.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

9. As I told the last set of Commissioners shortly after they were sworn-in five months ago on Wednesday 15th September 2021, our success in this arduous task draws largely from our integrity as election managers.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

8. As I welcome the new Commissioners, I urge you to deploy your vast knowledge and diverse experiences to the service of the country as unbiased referees. I am confident that you will join us in further extending the frontiers of free and fair elections in Nigeria.

7. In line with the Commission‚Äôs policy, Mr. Ijalaye is hereby deployed to Ogun State as the new REC. The current REC for Ogun State, Mr. Olusegun Agbaje, is redeployed to Lagos State. Handing and taking over is to be concluded by Monday 28th February 2022.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

6. Similarly, a new Resident Electoral Commissioner (REC) has just been sworn-in. He is Olaniyi Olaleye Babalola Ijalaye, a legal practitioner. He fills the vacancy for Ondo State following the swearing-in of Mr. Sam Olumekun as a National Commissioner.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu
5. With your appointment, the Commission now has the full compliment of 12 National Commissioners.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

3. while Mr. Kenneth Nnamdi Ukeagu has been a career staff of the Commission, rising to the rank of Director. ¬†The other two National Commissioners are Mrs. Rhoda Gumus, a Professor of Engineering, and Modibbo Abubakar Alkali, a retired Major General of the Nigerian Army.

2. Mrs. May Agbamuche-Mbu, a lawyer, and Malam Mohammed Haruna, a journalist, have been re-appointed to serve for a second term. Mr. Sam Olumekun, a retired civil servant, has served for two terms as Resident Electoral Commissioner (REC) in many States, including Lagos
1. It is my pleasure to welcome you all to this occasion. Earlier today, six National Commissioners were sworn-in by the President. Four of them are not new to the Commission.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

INEC Restates Faith In BVAS, Vows To Tackle Identified Challengeshttps://t.co/YVTrp3Bk0v https://t.co/JnILATn4Mq
23. The review of Election Day administration in general is one of the issues to be discussed at this meeting.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

22. The Commission remains convinced that the deployment of technology in our elections safeguards the integrity of the vote and provides a better guarantee for electoral credibility than the best manual process.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

21. We will review and improve its functionality for biometric accreditation of voters in the forthcoming bye-elections and off-season Governorship elections before the 2023 General Election.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

20. Secondly, to replace the Z-pad for uploading the polling unit results to the INEC Result Viewing Portal (IReV) in real-time on Election Day. So far, the BVAS has performed optimally in verifying the authenticity of PVCs and uploading images of Polling Unit results to the IReV

19. When the Commission introduced the BVAS last year, the compact device was intended to achieve two objectives. First is the verification of the genuineness of the Permanent Voters‚Äô Cards (PVCs) and the fingerprint or facial authentication of voters during accreditation.
18. However, the challenges to the optimal functionality of the device are acknowledged and we are working on them.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

17. The outcome of elections conducted since the introduction of BVAS in the Isoko South I State Constituency bye-election, followed by the Anambra State Governorship election and most recently in the FCT Area Council election has been positively adjudged by observers as credible

16. The creation of Registration Area Centres (RACs) improved the early opening of polls. The benefits of these new innovations to the electoral process and the credibility of our elections have been enormous.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

15. On Election Day administration, the Commission has over the years made giant strides in improving electoral logistics, staff recruitment, training, deployment and the introduction of technology for voter verification and authentication.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

14. Over the next few weeks, the Commission will intensify efforts to address the issue ahead of the forthcoming Ekiti and Osun Governorship elections and ultimately the 2023 General Election. Finding a solution to this issue is one of the reasons for convening this meeting.

13. While this lofty goal has been achieved in many States, there are still congested Polling Units and other Polling Units with between 0 and 50 voters as we saw in some of the recent elections.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

12. The idea is to decongest the densely populated polling units by converting the erstwhile Voting Points (VPs) and Voting Point Settlements (VPS) to Polling Units and relocating some of them to unserved and underserved areas to make it easier for voters on Election Day.

11. Closely related to the issue of CVR is the balanced distribution of voters to polling units nationwide. Last year, the Commission achieved the historic feat of expanding voter access to polling units nationwide.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu
10. The devolution of the CVR exercise to other designated centres is one of the major issues for discussion at this meeting.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

9. Similarly, in order to provide more eligible voters with the opportunity to register, the Commission is considering the devolution of the exercise nationwide beyond our State and Local Government offices where the registration currently takes place.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu
8. In view of the forthcoming elections, the Commission has decided to devolve the CVR exercise to Ward level in both Ekiti and Osun States to enable more citizens register. Prof. Mahmood Yakubu
7. Even as we continue to conduct elections, the Continuous Voter Registration (CVR) exercise which started in June last year is now in its 3rd Quarter.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu
6. The Governorship election in Ekiti State will hold on Saturday 18th June while that of Osun State will be conducted a month later on Saturday 16th July 2022.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

5. The Commission has already displayed the personal particulars of the candidates in our State & Local Government offices in Ekiti State as required by law. For the Osun State election, party primaries begin tomorrow 16th February and end on 12th March 2022Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

4. In addition to the bye-elections, the end-of-tenure Ekiti and Osun State Governorship elections are fast approaching. Party primaries for the Ekiti election ended on 29th January 2022.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

3. Right now, the Commission is preparing to conduct bye-elections in four States of the Federation to fill six vacancies in the House of Representatives and some State Houses of Assembly. Prof. Mahmood Yakubu
2. Today‚Äôs meeting is coming a few days after the Area Council election in the Federal Capital Territory (FCT) held three days ago on Saturday 12th February 2022.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

1. I welcome our Resident Electoral Commissioners to our first meeting this year. Our last meeting in December last year was held in the aftermath of the Anambra State Governorship election.Prof. Mahmood Kakubu

21. Use the immense powers that you have for good causes. Continue to support INEC to conduct free, fair, credible, & inclusive elections. We are not asking for blind support. We are always open to constructive but not destructive criticisms.Thank you for your attention @rot1930

22. Malcolm X once said, and I quote: ‚ÄúThe media‚Äôs the most powerful entity on earth. They have the power to make the innocent guilty and to make the guilty innocent.‚Äù This is both a positive and negative statement. @rot1930

21. Our country will face many dangers if journalists fail in their responsibilities. The media is the only hope of the ordinary person. The media speaks truth to power, and your ability to hold public office holders to account is such a unique one. @rot1930

20. However, as much as we can, let us try in our individual and collective capacities to work for the preservation of our democracy and the improvement of the electoral process. We have no other country except Nigeria. @rot1930

19. Ladies and gentlemen, I want to make an appeal as one of you. Before I assumed my current role, I was in the mainstream media. So I know the powers that you have. I also appreciate the challenges. Things are pretty tricky, and we are operating under challenging circumstances.

17. In addition, you will appreciate the regulatory powers given to the Commission to manage the electoral system. @rot1930
16. Then find time out of your busy schedules to read the documents. If you do this, you will understand why INEC acts the way it does because these laws guide all our actions. @rot1930

15. As media professionals covering politics and electoral matters, I would suggest that you get a personal copy of the Electoral Act 2010 as amended and the 1999 Constitution of the Federal Republic of Nigeria (as amended). @rot1930
14. There is another thing. Many media practitioners tend to question some of our actions. Each time we provide answers, we quote the relevant sections of the law. @rot1930

13. If you haven‚Äôt done so, please follow us on our social media handles, and you will be glad you did. You will find a lot of helpful information in real-time that you can use to prepare your reports from time to time. @rot1930

12. Apart from our regular press statements, we also have social media platforms like Twitter, Facebook and Instagram. We upload a great deal of content and documents to these platforms. We also have an online newspaper ‚Äì https://t.co/jY5SGGN7h8 and MyINEC App. @rot1930

11. I wish to draw the attention of all participants to the various channels that the Commission has established, which could serve as good sources of news. They can also be used for research purposes. @rot1930

10. However, we also expect feedback from participants regarding comments and questions for which robust clarifications will be provided. I am sure the Head of Station at Hot FM will speak along this line during her presentation. @rot1930

9. During this meeting, our National Commissioner, Barrister Festus Okoye, Resident Electoral Commissioner, Alhaji Yahaya Bello and Director of ICT, Engineer Chidi Nwafor, will speak on these critical areas. @rot1930
8. The second reason is that Commission has new information regarding the upcoming elections that we would like the FCT citizens to know. @rot1930
7. We will be holding quarterly consultative meetings with our critical stakeholders this week, beginning from tomorrow, and the media is one of these vital partners. @rot1930
6. We thank you for what you have done in the past, what you are doing now and what you intend to do in the future. We will continue to accord the media the respect that it deserves. @rot1930
5. Consequently, we are also able to respond more proactively to their needs. The Commission profoundly appreciates this continuous collaboration and would never take it for granted. @rot1930

3. When INEC speaks, acts, issues press statements, reacts to false allegations or debunks conspiracy theories, and Nigerians get to hear about it, it is because you, media professionals, have reported on it through your respective channels. @rot1930

Since the conclusion of the 2019 General Election, the Commission, working with the security agencies, has so far conducted four end-of-tenure Governorship elections and 28 out of 32 bye-elections.

.. facilities and deliberate on how best to protect them.I believe that we can dig deep and draw from the Commission‚Äôs longstanding partnership with communities in this regard, in addition to depending on the invaluable support of our security agencies.

...and appeal to them to continue to see INEC property as both national and local assets to be protected.In the light of the current circumstances, today‚Äôs meeting with RECs, who lead our offices in the States, will take briefings from across the country on threats to INEC..

Even in the recent events of arson and vandalisation, many of them have demonstrated exceptional willingness to support the Commission.The Commission does not take such partnerships for granted. I wish to thank our host communities in all parts of the country...

They have over the years supported the Commission during all electoral activities from CVR to the conduct of polls. Some of them actually donated the land on which some of our Local Government offices are built.

I am glad that some of them are already doing so.For this reason, I must put on record the fantastic partnership between the Commission and the communities we serve. These communities share with the Commission the commitment of improving electoral services to Nigerians.

However, it has become imperative to call on all and sundry, particularly communities where these assets are located, to see themselves as owners and custodians of these facilities and assist the Commission in protecting them.

The Commission will certainly work with the security agencies to deal with the perpetrators of these heinous crimes according to the law. To this end, a meeting with all the security agencies is holding on Monday 24th May 2021.

These facilities are not only limited to voting but also used for other critical electoral activities such as voter registration, the coordination of stakeholder engagements and voter education and sensitisation.
Replacing these facilities in the prevailing economic circumstances will indeed be a tall order, thereby adversely affecting electoral services in the same communities.
Therefore, targeting such important national assets and repositories of electoral materials that took time and enormous resources to procure cannot be justified.

...which may undermine the Commission‚Äôs capacity to organise elections and dent the nation‚Äôs electoral process. The facilities of the Commission are there to serve the local communities for the most fundamental aspect of democratic governance, which is elections.

I most warmly welcome the Directing Staff of Department of Administration, Resource Persons and indeed all participants to this workshop and ¬†It is my honour and privilege to declare this workshop open.I wish you all fruitful deliberation.
I urge participants to give this workshop all the focus and attention it deserve, so as to be better equipped to deliver on the mandate assigned to you.
This workshop for Welfare Desk Officers is not only timely, but also a necessary corollary to the efficient administration of the Commission‚Äôs ¬† human asset.

I therefore have no doubt that, this workshop will provide the platform ¬†for knowledge sharing and capacity building, so as to ensure that, this sphere of activity accords with current trends and best practices.

While we pray for the repose of the soul of the dead and quick recovery of the injured in that unfortunate incident, we also ask that you remember us in prayer , as we conduct the bye-election here in Delta State .

We must always have at the back of our mind that, nobody‚Äôs political ambition is worth the loss of one life, how much more the regrettable killing of three persons , in the truncated State Constituency bye-election in Ekit, over the weekend .
Nevertheless I want to use this opportunity to make an appeal for peaceful conduct, before, during and after the bye-election, by Deltans and Isoko North people in particular.

It is on this premise we assure all adhoc staff who would be mobilized for the Isoko North State Constituency bye-election of adequate security, and welfare cover, should the unexpected happen, God forbid.
Some of the key aspects of the Commission‚Äôs welfare policy for adhoc staff, life insurance policy, accident insurance, among others.
This workshop bears eloquent testimony to the commitment of the Commission to the welfare of not only its permanent staff , but also all cadre of adhoc staff.

On the subject matter of this particular workshop, you will agree with me on the inevitability of certain occurrences in human life, more so ¬†for those in the service of the Commission; ¬†some of which include sickness, accident, deaths and retirements, etc .
The choice of Asaba, to host this all important workshop speaks to the serenity and ambience prevalent in the State Capital, which makes it a conference and workshop destination of choice.
It is therefore with delight I welcome participants to the 2-Day Sensitization Workshop for INEC Welfare Desk Officers, drawn from the Southern States.

The choice is for each and every one of us to determine how to locate himself in the new scheme of the operations of the Commission.

Any staff who cannot locate himself within these changes and or adapt to the new realities of the electoral process will sadly find himself to be a burden if not an impediment to the wheel of progress.
The changes the Commission is making are fundamental and with the prospect of altering the electoral landscape of the country.

It is imperative that staff of the Commission at this juncture should be properly equipped, especially being at home with relevant technologies. The times equally demand staff that is highly professional and ethical.

This workshop and training program comes at a time of unprecedented action and impactful decisions in the Commission. It is expected that every staff of the Commission will play an important role in the new scheme of things.

Stakeholders have a central role to play in addressing the challenge, especially by committing to supporting the Commission‚Äôs efforts to find solutions & assisting to depoliticize the issueBy Barr. Presentation of expansion of Voter Access to Polling Units by INEC National Commissioner, Barr. Festus Okoye at the ongoing consultative meeting with the Media.#VoterAccesstoPUs https://t.co/5XH6QEU6jI

Today‚Äôs meeting with the Media is in furtherance of our consultations with stakeholders. There will be a presentation followed by discussion. Let us work together to finally solve the 25-year old problem of access to Polling Units in Nigeria.#VoterAccesstoPUs https://t.co/LRZ5OMsWpx

We came to the conclusion that our genuine intention may not have been properly communicated for input by Nigerians. We also tried to solve the problem too close to General Elections. The exercise was therefore misunderstood and politicised.

As you are probably aware, the Commission has reviewed the previous efforts at expanding voter access to Polling Units in 2007, 2014 and just before the 2019 General Election and why they were unsuccessful.

The voters‚Äô register increased to 84,004,084 by 2019. We envisage that by the next Election in 2023, the population of registered voter may be twice the number projected in 1996. Yet, the number of PUs remains the same. This is a national problem. It must be addressed in earnest. https://t.co/OmM7rcCJcM

I am glad to note that today‚Äôs meeting focuses on the expansion of voter access to Polling Units. This matter is at the heart of electoral democracy. Every eligible citizen has the right to register and vote in democratic elections. https://t.co/c1W6m77pv6
Citizens‚Äô right to vote must be exercised in a conducive and safe environment, particularly in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic.

... in virtually all democracies around the world. I am confident that by working together, we will make history by finally solving this 25-year old problem of expanding voter access to polling units in Nigeria.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

We hope that by doing so, we will better communicate the Commission‚Äôs intention to Nigerians and invite input across the board on how to address this problem in the immediate term and hopefully establish the framework for future adjustments as the need arises, as is the case...
Today‚Äôs meeting with CSOs is in furtherance of our consultations with stakeholders. There will be a presentation followed by discussion.
We have also prepared satellite imageries of the location of polling units across the country and produced still pictures and videos to demonstrate the difficulties faced by voters on Election Day.

Learning from experience, the Commission has now decided to start early and to engage with Nigerians by consulting widely. We have worked hard in the last two months and produced a Discussion Paper entitled ‚ÄúThe State of Voter Access to Polling Units in Nigeria‚Äù.
We came to the conclusion that our genuine intention may not have been properly communicated for input by Nigerians and therefore misunderstood and politicised.
The Commission has reviewed the previous efforts at expanding voter access to polling units in 2007, 2014 and just before the 2019 General Election and why they were unsuccessful.

I wish to reassure the people of Ondo State that the Commission has taken every step to ensure that the election on Saturday is free, fair, credible, inclusive & safe.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu
Once again, I welcome you all to this meeting and look forward to clarifying any grey areas during the interaction session.

By doing so, the Commission will receive first-hand information as the election is going on. At the same time, citizens can contact us on our various platforms such as the INEC Citizens Contact Centre (ICCC) Hot line in addition to our Twitter, Facebook & Instagram accounts.

On Election Day, the national headquarters of INEC will monitor the election throughout Ondo State. Our Zoom Situation Room will receive live reports from the field and respond to issues that may arise. Accredited observers and the media will also be invited to join at intervals.

We have been assured by the security agencies that thugs & their sponsors will not have the freedom to move around freely to disrupt the election or collation of results. The IG of Police who is here personally will speak about the strategy to safeguard the electoral process.
The people of Ondo State must be allowed to freely vote for their preferred candidate without inducement or harassment.
... attack on INEC officials or compelling them to declare unofficial results.

The Commission is determined that no one will benefit from impunity or be rewarded for bad behaviour such as vote-buying, ballot box snatching and stuffing, multiple voting, hijacking and diversion of election materials, disruption of collation, falsification of results,...
However, this will not happen where the process is disrupted by violence or malpractices.

As the eligible voters in Ondo State go to the polls on Saturday, I wish to renew my appeal to all political parties, candidates and their supporters for peaceful conduct. Votes will count. Polling unit level results will be uploaded for public view.

This is a mandatory requirement and where they are deliberately avoided to undermine the integrity of the electoral process, the result for the affected polling unit will be declared void in line with the Commission‚Äôs regulations and guidelines.
I must quickly add that the Smart Card Readers will also be deployed for voter verification and authentication.

Anyone interested in viewing polling unit level result in real-time can simply visit our website (https://t.co/2cNanKnOcv) to register and create an account. So far, 58,229 viewers have registered on the portal as at Thursday last week.

This technology was first deployed in the Nasarawa Central State Constituency bye-election and, most recently, in the Edo State Governorship election. The same technology will be deployed for the Ondo State Governorship election this Saturday.

To further underscore our commitment to a credible and transparent electoral process in Nigeria, the Commission introduced the z-pad to upload polling unit level results on a dedicated portal (INEC RESULT VIEWING - IReV).

For this reason, the Commission has translated and published the policy on conducting elections in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic as well as the Voters‚Äô Code of Conduct into braille. We have also produced posters to guide hearing-impaired voters.

In order to ensure greater awareness and effective participation of all citizens in the electoral process, the Commission is deploying magnifying glasses and braille ballot guides to assist Persons with Disabilities (PWDs) to vote unaided.
All eligible voters will have equal opportunity to exercise their right to vote.

On this note, I would like to appeal to all election officials, transport providers, polling agents, election observers & the media to ensure compliance with the advisory by health authorities. Voting in safety is a critical component of elections in the era of COVID-19 pandemic.

Working with health authorities, we will continue to enforce safety measures at polling units, including the compulsory wearing of face masks and the provision of non-pharmaceutical interventions such as hand sanitizers and infra-red thermometers at PUs and collation centres.
We had useful discussions with the security agencies and anti-corruption agencies on how to deal with vote buying during elections.

In response, we have engaged with land and maritime transport owners for forward and reverse logistics to and from land and riverine locations. We have engaged additional 104 Registration Area Technical Support staff to respond rapidly to issues with Card Readers on Election Day.

For this reason, we identified 16 areas of improvement, including logistics, prompt response to Smart Card Reader glitches on Election Day, the menace of vote buying during elections and compliance with COVID-19 protocols.
The Commission has reviewed the last Governorship election in Edo State. We are determined to continue improving on our performance.

I want to assure political parties and candidates that we will remain focused on our processes and procedures. Let me reiterate to all stakeholders that the Commission will not take any action to the advantage or disadvantage of any political party or candidate.
I wish to assure all eligible voters that every vote will count and only the choice made by the people of Ondo State will determine the outcome of the election.
Our commitment is to ensure that the choice of who becomes the next Governor of Ondo State is entirely in the hands of the voters.
I have spent the last two days here in Ondo State evaluating our preparations and I am pleased with what I have seen.

I wish to specifically thank all the agencies in ICCES, especially the lead agency, the Nigeria Police, for their continued support and professionalism as we prepare for the election. In short, the Commission is ready for the election.
We have made adequate arrangements with the Federal Fire Service to ensure that such incidents do not occur again.

In response to the unfortunate fire incident last month in which we lost all our Smart Card Readers in Ondo State, we have moved enough replacements from Oyo State and configured them for the election on Saturday.

We have made arrangements for the movement of personnel and materials to electoral locations in all 3,009 polling units and 203 electoral wards across the State. This afternoon, the Central Bank will deliver all sensitive materials for the election to its Akure branch.
We warned our officials (ad hoc and regular staff) to be professional and non-partisan in the discharge of their assigned responsibilities. Voter education and sensitisation is ongoing.
Similarly, we have recruited, trained and screened all categories of ad hoc staff for the election. We have delivered non-sensitive materials to all the 18 Local Government Areas of Ondo State.

We conferred with the National Peace Committee under the leadership of our former Head of State General Abdulsalami A. Abubakar GCFR, which has invited political parties and candidates to sign a Peace Accord here in Akure tomorrow.

We have also interacted with the security agencies at National and State level. We consulted with, and sought for the support and blessings of, the Ondo State Council of Obas. We met with religious leaders, civil society organisations and the media.

Since the Commission released the timetable and schedule of activities for the Ondo State Governorship election eight months ago on 6th February 2020, we have engaged with political parties and their candidates in several meetings.
On behalf of the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC), let me join the Resident Electoral Commissioner (REC) for Ondo State to once again warmly welcome you all to this meeting.

Press StatementOriginal manufacturers of Electronic Voting Machines (EVMs) have been invited for a virtual or practical demonstration to enable the Commission evaluate the available technology for the purposes of electronic voting... https://t.co/DovpjaSzl9
Engr. Chidi Nwafor explaining the Modalities for the Demonstration of Electronic Voting Machines (EVMs) @ the Conference Room, INEC Headquarters, Abuja. https://t.co/QkjbeFQEn3
INEC Chairman, Prof. Mahmood Yakubu remarks at the ongoing Demonstration of Electronic Voting Machines (EVMs) @ the Conference Room, INEC Headquarters, Abuja. https://t.co/ADniDwjVL3
National Commission, Dr. Muhammad M. Lecky, welcome remarks at the ongoing Demonstration of Electronic Voting Machines (EVMs) @ the Conference Room, INEC Headquarters, Abuja. https://t.co/8jLyIyN4sp

The Commission is aware that Nigerians want us to deepen the use of technology in elections. Let me reassure Nigerians that the Commission is committed to expediting the process leading to the deployment of EVMs in elections in earnest.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

I wish to emphasise that this is only a demonstration that will enable the Commission to evaluate the available technology & where necessary finetune our specifications before proceeding to the next stage which will involve the participation of stakeholders.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu
Over 40 companies that indicated interest will demonstrate to the Commission how their IT solutions meet our specifications. Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

The Commission developed the specifications of the functions required of the machine. After extensive discussion and review, the Commission took the decision to invite original manufacturers of EVMs around the world for a virtual or practical demonstration of the machines.

The Commission has been working on the deployment of technology in voting during elections to replace the current manual system which is tedious & requires enormous logistics to deliver huge quantities of printed materials & a large number of adhoc staff to administer the process
Today, the Commission is taking yet another decisive step towards the full automation of the electoral process.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

Most significantly, the Commission now uploads polling unit level results in real-time on Election Day to a portal for public view. These are significant innovations that have deepened the transparency & credibility of elections and the electoral process in Nigeria.Prof. Yakubu

More recently, the introduction of a number of portals has facilitated the seamless nomination of candidates for elective offices by political parties as well as the accreditation of observers and the media.Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

In addition, the combination of biometric voters‚Äô cards commonly known as the Permanent Voter‚Äôs Card (PVC) and the Smart Card Reader (SCR) have revolutionised the accreditation of voters during elections. Prof. Mahmood Yakubu
The biometric register of voters has been updated continuously. At the moment, the INEC register of voters is the largest data base of citizens in Nigeria. Prof. Mahmood Yakubu

I welcome you all to this occasion which is another giant step in the Commission‚Äôs continuous effort to deepen electoral integrity in Nigeria through the deployment of technology. Over the years, the Commission has been automating the critical pillars of the processProf. Yakubu

CONDUCT OF BYE-ELECTIONS It is to be noted that in addition to d Governorship elections in Edo&Ondo States, d Commission has received official declaration of vacancies for 4 Senatorial Districts &read reports of the passing of a Senator & 4 members of some State House Assembly

To this end, the Commission will meet with:1.Resident Electoral Commissioners (RECs) on Saturday, 30th May 2020;2.Political Parties on Monday, 1st June 2020;3.Civil Society Groups on 2nd June 2020; and 4.The Media on 3rd June 2020.

STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENTSIn view of the end of tenure Governorship elections in Edo and Ondo States scheduled for 19th September 2020 and 10th October 2020 respectively, the Commission will flag off robust engagements with its critical stakeholders to present the Policy Document

The Commission remains committed to raising public confidence in the electoral process in spite of the challenges posed by the pandemic and to regularly communicate its actions and challenges to the public.

However, in so doing it will put a premium on public safety and mitigation of health risks from COVID-19. Citizens must be assured that they will be safe while participating as voters, candidates and officials.

Conducting elections in a pandemic such as COVID-19 is yet uncharted waters. Only very few jurisdictions have any experience with this. That notwithstanding, the Commission is committed to conducting all elections that are due within the extant legal framework.

The clean copy of d policy document, which will be released on Mon 25th May 2020, covers health&legal issues, election planning&operations, election day&post-election activities,voter registration,political parties, election observation,electoral security&deployment of technology

The general purpose of the Policy is to enable officials&staff of the Commission to understand&respond adequately to the challenges of conducting elections in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic & to provide a guide for engagement with stakeholders as they prepare for elections

#INEC Swears Two New Resident Electoral Commissioners Inhttps://t.co/7pvtdAvXpP https://t.co/26v0hsWAXs

They are Dr Alalibo Sinikiem Johnson from Bayelsa State and Umar Mukhtar Gajiram from Borno State. Dr Johnson is from Bayelsa State and replaces the former REC of Cross River State while Mr. Gajiram replaces the former REC of Taraba State who died a few months ago.

You will recall that recently, the Senate confirmed the nomination of two Resident Electoral Commissioners (RECs) as a result of the vacancies that exist in two States of the Federation. Consequently, two new RECs have just been sworn-in.
